Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in the "Southeastern Analysis Meeting 2017" that will be held March 17-19, 2017, on the campus of the University of Tennessee.

This event is the latest installment in a thirty-two-year-long series of conferences covering a wide spectrum of subareas of analysis. In particular, the Southeastern Analysis Meeting (SEAM) has become the leading conference venue in the U.S. for function-theoretic operator theory. SEAM 2017 will again span a broad swath of analysis, featuring five plenary speakers who will address topics in operator theory (Alexandru Aleman, Ken Davidson, Alexei Poltoratski, Karl-Mikael Perfekt); harmonic analysis (Betsy Stovall); and frame theory, sampling theory, and interpolation theory (Shahaf Nitzan). The conference program provides ample opportunity for graduate students, postdocs, and other young scientists to present their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided partial funding for the 33rd Southeastern Analysis Meeting. The meeting took place March 17-19, 2017 on the campus of the University of Tennessee, Knoxville.  The purpose of the meeting was to bring together experienced and junior researchers in the broad area of analysis, and it attracted participation of 72 researchers from all over the United States and foreign countries.

Six plenary speakers had been selected to speak about some exciting recent developments in complex analysis, operator theory, Fourier analysis, and applications. Additionally there were 46 contributed talks, many of which were given by early career researchers. The Conference program facilitated interactions between all participants.

The National Science Foundation grant was used to defray travel expenses mostly for junior participants. Specifically, 9 Assistant Professors, 8 Postdoctoral Researchers, and 25 graduate students were able to attend the meeting because of the NSF support. Participation in this conference should have a direct impact on the future productivity of these young scientists both in teaching and in research. Thus the conference has played its part in supporting the NSF’s mission in promoting the economic and scientific growth of the US.

On the conference website http://www.math.utk.edu/SEAM/ one can still find the program, abstracts of talks, and the lecture notes for many of the presentations.
